HOPKINS TO PARADE
EVE OF U. OF M. GAME
There will be a parade the
night before the Maryland
game according to Parks,
cheer leader. This parade
will take the place of the heretofore annual St. John's
parade.
The cheer leaders that night
will distribute torches of all
colors which will be carried
during the procession. The
two lower classes are expected
to back the parade to the limit
this year and make a precedent
for coming years. It is not
known at this time whether or
not Maryland will be burned
in effigy, as has St. John's
formerly.

With the aims of its organization
summarily agreed upon, the Erasmian society of graduate students
last Tuesday evening inaugurated
the first of a series of monthly
meetings. J. A. Mogilnitsky, Russian exile, was the principal speaker of the occasion. Reading a paper
entitled "Soviet Russia as a Market," Mogilnitsky declared himself
vigorously opposed to the head-long
manner in which the Russian government was overthrown, but
ardently in favor of Russia's recognition by the various powers. He
vividly described the destitute state Frey, Ried, Wollenberg and
Mattingly for President
of the Soviet and pointed out the
virtues that such a recognition

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 19, 1929

NOTICE
Each senior is requested to
submit an informal photograph
of himself for use in the 1930
Hullabaloo. He will please turn
one in as soon as possible to
W. Scheid, P. 0. Box 1063.

HOPKINS ADDS P. M. C.
DEBATING TEAMS TO
TO GRIE SCHEDULE
BE CHOSEN TONINHT
Three or Four Teams Will Be St. John's Game To Be Advanced One Week
Formed
This evening at 5:00 P. M. in
Room B, Levering Hall, a number
of intercollegiate debating teams to
represent the University both for
invasion and defense will be chosen.
Every member of the student body,
from freshman to senior, whether
or not he has had any previous debating experience will receive a
chance to represent the University
in some manner, and there will be
no candidate to receive preference
for any reason whatever. The
judging of the try-out will be intrusted to a few members of the
faculty.
Three and possibly four teams
will be chosen. One team, consisting of two men will be given a fouror five-day trip into the North during the Christmas holidays with all
expenses paid. A second team, for
which preference will be given
to Seniors, will debate against
Goucher during April. One or two
teams, which will be composed of
two or three men will be chosen to
represent Hopkins when other Universities visit Homewood.

Next year, Pennsylvania Military
College will be numbered among the
rivals of the Jay football team. The
Pennsylvanians will occupy the
place on the Hopkins schedule now
held by the St. John's team. Accordingly, the St. John's game will
be moved forward one week.
This circumstance was brought
about when St. John's College broke
relations with the Pennsylvania
Military College over the ruling
making freshmen ineligible for varsity football. The Cadets played
their freshmen in the P. M. C.-St.
John's game and so the break resulted. This left a vacancy in the
P. M. C. schedule, which they asked
Hopkins to fill.
Dr. Van Orman, Hopkins Coach,
has accepted their invitation. A
good game is expected to be the outcome of the Jay's northern invasion
as P. M. C. has a good reputation in
football circles.
The game with the Johnnies will
be held two weeks before Thanksgiving next year, instead of the
usual date. This leaves a date open
on their schedule, which is expected
to be filled in the near future, according to Riggs, St. John's coach.
The freshman ruling, which allows
no first-year men to play • on the
varsity, was adopted by St. John's
to go into effect next year. So far,
the onyl opponents affected is P.
M. C.

DR. CHRISTIE CHOSEN
HONORARY PRESIDENT
Dr. Christie was elected
honorary president of the
Senior Class at a meeting held
last Friday, according to a
report made by Warring,
president. At the meeting,
which was held immediately
following the taking of the
class picture, the Hullabaloo
situation was finally and officially settled by a unanimous
passing of the plan presented
by last year's Junior class officers. Unger, Hunt, and Golz
were admitted to this year's
graduating class by unanimously passing that body last
Friday.

HOPKINS LOSES
TO ST. JOHN'S
Bob McCartee Stars In 33-0
Victory For Johnnies
SCORES FOUR TIMES
Mills Plays Stellar Game At
Full Back
Last Saturday afternoon at
Homewood under a blue autumn
sky, Hopkins' ancient rival, St.
John's, defeated the Blue Jays, 33-0,
in a football game which was made
colorful by the flashy runs of Bob
McCartee, the 145-pound left halfback from Annapolis. This game
marked the 42nd clash between
these old rivals on the gridiron and
none of the usual spirit which is
always present when a Hopkins
team meets one from Annapolis was
lacking in the least bit. The crowd
of from 5,500 to 6,000 which
packed the stands on both sides
was moved many times by the spectacular playing of McCartee, who
ran up and down the turf of the
University Parkway gridiron, literally decorating the landscape with
thwarted Hopkins tacklers. This
Annapolis will o' the wisp literally
ran wild and the Hopkins eleven,
try as it may, could not bottle him
up, and, ably supported by very
strong interference he four times
crossed the Hopkins' goal line to
deposit the ball on the ground and
to score 24 points for his team as
a result of his brilliant broken-field
running.
Jays At A Loss

The Jays couldn't seem to get
within speaking distance of McCartee, and once he had crossed the
line of scrimmage, he ran like a
streak of greased lightning, and it
took a Charlie Paddock to keep up
with him. "Aside from breaking
away on some six or eight long nonscoring runs, some of the things the
elusive Annapolitan did were to run
20 and 55 yards for touchdowns,
gallop nine yards to another and
catch a 20-yard forward pass for a
fourth."
Hopkins Outplayed

The Jays were overmatched in
the game, especially on the wings
and in the backfield. The interior
of the line played well and St.
John's found it hard to buck
through. One of the reasons for
the success of the central section of
the line can be laid on the shoulders
of Mills, Hopkins' scrappy fullback,
who was always right on the job
and broke up many St. John's line
plays by dropping the pingskin
carrier almost in his tracks and before he was past the line of scrimmage. Mills played a wonderful defensive game during the entire time
and always seemed to be where he
was most needed at the right time.
St. John's Scores

Hopkins won the toss-up and
elected to receive. Armacost booted
the ball high and far and it landed
behind the Jays' goal line. On an
exchange of punts between Turnbull and Lynch the Johnnies gained
ground. On a long run by McCartee the ball was advanced to the
Jays' 10-yard line. Hopkins, with
its back to the wall, braced up and
stopped two successive rushes of the
Johnnies. On the next down, McCartee rounded left end for seven
yards, placing the ball on the threeyard line, and Armacost, on the last
down, carried the ball over for St.
John's first score. McCartee placekicked goal for the extra point.

University of Michigan has
banned autos! At any rate, autos
are forbidden to all those students
who have not yet united in holy
wedlock. Have the students protested, petitioned, and otherwise expressed their disapproval of the
edict? Up until the time for the
writing of this article, they have
not. On the other hand, this ban
has produced an altogether unexpected result, that is a result not
expected by those responsible for its
passage. A record number of students claim to be married in order to
get permission to drive the cherished vechicles. A number of others
are thinking about advertising for
mates. In the words of one senior,
"I'll marry anybody in order to get
permission to drive a car." What
price driving?

Los Angeles have recently held a
debate on the topic, "Resolved:
That women should pay their share
of the expenses of a date." Permit
us to recommend this as a subject

ANOTHER TRADITION CRUMBLES ALONG
WITH FRESHMEN REGULATIONS ET AL
The progress of light and learning at this revered institution has
decreed that the St. John's parade
become a thing of the past. One
by one the traditions fall. No more
shall Charles Street witness the
spectacle of enthusiastic students
marching to the strain of Hopkins
melodies. No more will the fair
damsels of Goucher College be
aroused out of dormitory beds at
nine o'clock to listen to the serenaders. No more shall Sun Square
be the scene of the final beheading
and cremation of the effigy of old
St. John's.
As we shed a last tear and turn
to our books for consolation let us
recall events of former years:
Every Freshman brought two
boxes of ample size and deposited
them in a pile behind the C. E. Hall
as per instructions of sopphomores.
In the course of a day or two the
pile has grown to enormous proportions. So much for preliminaries
and now our picture again changes.
The University Officials and police have put a ban on this part of
the celebration. What can be done?
Will the bon-fire be started anyhow? Page Frank Merriwell.
Seven o'clock and utter darkness.
A hugh crowd around the pile of
boxes, thirty feet high—just aching
to get hot. Here and there small
groups of students are planning
What can be done? Policemen, some fifty strong prevent anyone from getting near the hugh bier.
St. John's in dummy form, is rest-

ing calmly upon the great heap, and
no doubt is thumbing his nose at
the frustrated and disappointed
student body.
Suddenly, without warning, a
collegiate Ford is seen hurtling at
a terrific speed right for the crowd.
The crowd, awe struck and frightened, moves aside; policemen are
cleverly taken care of; the car flies
past dropping a flaming torch as it
goes, and the deed is done.
As the last flaming ember dies
away the parade begins its march
down Charles Street. Goucher
College' is serenaded, looked over,
dated up, and the parade moves on.
The semaphore station at Charles
Street and North Avenue is converted into a cheer leaders stand.
Mysterious chemicals on the car
tracks explode loudly. Finally one
great mass of hoarse throats gather
at the Sun Square and yell and
yell and sing, and announce in no
uncertain terms that the good ole'
"Black and Blue" eleven will throttle decisively an Orange and Black
jerseyed team.

The staff of the 1929 Hullabaloo will sponsor a Thanksgiving dance at 9:00 P. M.
Thanksgiving Day at the
Southern Hotel. This dance,
which was to be the regular
after-the-game dance of the

over to the Hullabaloo staff
in order that they might make
up a large deficit incurred
from publishing last year's
Hullabaloo. A large attendance is hoped for, so that the
deficit may be made up. A
charge of $1.00, stag or couple, will be made.

Armacose Scores

The second quarter was still
young when McCartee scooped up
the ball and ran it back 25 yards.
Dublin followed, and matched this
run with another for the same gain,
again placing St. John's ill a scoring position. In two downs, with
Lynch and Dublin bucking the line,
the Johnnies gained a first down,
and the ball rested on Hopkins'
eight-yard line. Over again the Jays
braced themselves, but Armacost
took the joy out of life for them
by running around the right end for
six points.
Fourth Quarter Lively

Early in the last period St. John's
scored its fourth touchdown, resulting from some more of McCartee's elusive running. After
running a kick back 30 yards, to,
the Jays' 20-yard line, on the next
yards to cross the Hopkins' goal
from Lynch and went over for a
touchdown.
About six minutes still remained
to be played when McCartee broke
loose for the last time. He took
the ball on his own.team's 45-yard
line and by sidestepping, spinning,
eluding tacklers and running like a
scared rabbit, he was able to run 55
yards to cros sthe Hopkins' goal
line for St. John's last touchdown_

minutes of the third quarter. On
the defense Hopkins played well,
but it was plainly brought out that
what is lacking is a good offensive
machine.

HOPKINS TO PARADE
EVE OF U. OF M. GAME
There will be a parade the
night before the Maryland
game according to Parks,
cheer leader. This parade
will take the place of the heretofore annual St. John's
parade.
The cheer leaders that night
will distribute torches of all
colors which will be carried
during the procession. The
two lower classes are expected
to back the parade to the limit
this year and make a precedent
for coming years. It is not
known at this time whether or
not Maryland will be burned
in effigy, as has St. John's
formerly.

With the aims of its organization
summarily agreed upon, the Erasmian society of graduate students
last Tuesday evening inaugurated
the first of a series of monthly
meetings. J. A. Mogilnitsky, Russian exile, was the principal speaker of the occasion. Reading a paper
entitled "Soviet Russia as a Market," Mogilnitsky declared himself
vigorously opposed to the head-long
manner in which the Russian government was overthrown, but
ardently in favor of Russia's recognition by the various powers. He
vividly described the destitute state Frey, Ried, Wollenberg and
Mattingly for President
of the Soviet and pointed out the
virtues that such a recognition

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 19, 1929

NOTICE
Each senior is requested to
submit an informal photograph
of himself for use in the 1930
Hullabaloo. He will please turn
one in as soon as possible to
W. Scheid, P. 0. Box 1063.

HOPKINS ADDS P. M. C.
DEBATING TEAMS TO
TO GRIE SCHEDULE
BE CHOSEN TONINHT
Three or Four Teams Will Be St. John's Game To Be Advanced One Week
Formed
This evening at 5:00 P. M. in
Room B, Levering Hall, a number
of intercollegiate debating teams to
represent the University both for
invasion and defense will be chosen.
Every member of the student body,
from freshman to senior, whether
or not he has had any previous debating experience will receive a
chance to represent the University
in some manner, and there will be
no candidate to receive preference
for any reason whatever. The
judging of the try-out will be intrusted to a few members of the
faculty.
Three and possibly four teams
will be chosen. One team, consisting of two men will be given a fouror five-day trip into the North during the Christmas holidays with all
expenses paid. A second team, for
which preference will be given
to Seniors, will debate against
Goucher during April. One or two
teams, which will be composed of
two or three men will be chosen to
represent Hopkins when other Universities visit Homewood.

Next year, Pennsylvania Military
College will be numbered among the
rivals of the Jay football team. The
Pennsylvanians will occupy the
place on the Hopkins schedule now
held by the St. John's team. Accordingly, the St. John's game will
be moved forward one week.
This circumstance was brought
about when St. John's College broke
relations with the Pennsylvania
Military College over the ruling
making freshmen ineligible for varsity football. The Cadets played
their freshmen in the P. M. C.-St.
John's game and so the break resulted. This left a vacancy in the
P. M. C. schedule, which they asked
Hopkins to fill.
Dr. Van Orman, Hopkins Coach,
has accepted their invitation. A
good game is expected to be the outcome of the Jay's northern invasion
as P. M. C. has a good reputation in
football circles.
The game with the Johnnies will
be held two weeks before Thanksgiving next year, instead of the
usual date. This leaves a date open
on their schedule, which is expected
to be filled in the near future, according to Riggs, St. John's coach.
The freshman ruling, which allows
no first-year men to play • on the
varsity, was adopted by St. John's
to go into effect next year. So far,
the onyl opponents affected is P.
M. C.

DR. CHRISTIE CHOSEN
HONORARY PRESIDENT
Dr. Christie was elected
honorary president of the
Senior Class at a meeting held
last Friday, according to a
report made by Warring,
president. At the meeting,
which was held immediately
following the taking of the
class picture, the Hullabaloo
situation was finally and officially settled by a unanimous
passing of the plan presented
by last year's Junior class officers. Unger, Hunt, and Golz
were admitted to this year's
graduating class by unanimously passing that body last
Friday.

HOPKINS LOSES
TO ST. JOHN'S
Bob McCartee Stars In 33-0
Victory For Johnnies
SCORES FOUR TIMES
Mills Plays Stellar Game At
Full Back
Last Saturday afternoon at
Homewood under a blue autumn
sky, Hopkins' ancient rival, St.
John's, defeated the Blue Jays, 33-0,
in a football game which was made
colorful by the flashy runs of Bob
McCartee, the 145-pound left halfback from Annapolis. This game
marked the 42nd clash between
these old rivals on the gridiron and
none of the usual spirit which is
always present when a Hopkins
team meets one from Annapolis was
lacking in the least bit. The crowd
of from 5,500 to 6,000 which
packed the stands on both sides
was moved many times by the spectacular playing of McCartee, who
ran up and down the turf of the
University Parkway gridiron, literally decorating the landscape with
thwarted Hopkins tacklers. This
Annapolis will o' the wisp literally
ran wild and the Hopkins eleven,
try as it may, could not bottle him
up, and, ably supported by very
strong interference he four times
crossed the Hopkins' goal line to
deposit the ball on the ground and
to score 24 points for his team as
a result of his brilliant broken-field
running.
Jays At A Loss

The Jays couldn't seem to get
within speaking distance of McCartee, and once he had crossed the
line of scrimmage, he ran like a
streak of greased lightning, and it
took a Charlie Paddock to keep up
with him. "Aside from breaking
away on some six or eight long nonscoring runs, some of the things the
elusive Annapolitan did were to run
20 and 55 yards for touchdowns,
gallop nine yards to another and
catch a 20-yard forward pass for a
fourth."
Hopkins Outplayed

The Jays were overmatched in
the game, especially on the wings
and in the backfield. The interior
of the line played well and St.
John's found it hard to buck
through. One of the reasons for
the success of the central section of
the line can be laid on the shoulders
of Mills, Hopkins' scrappy fullback,
who was always right on the job
and broke up many St. John's line
plays by dropping the pingskin
carrier almost in his tracks and before he was past the line of scrimmage. Mills played a wonderful defensive game during the entire time
and always seemed to be where he
was most needed at the right time.
St. John's Scores

Hopkins won the toss-up and
elected to receive. Armacost booted
the ball high and far and it landed
behind the Jays' goal line. On an
exchange of punts between Turnbull and Lynch the Johnnies gained
ground. On a long run by McCartee the ball was advanced to the
Jays' 10-yard line. Hopkins, with
its back to the wall, braced up and
stopped two successive rushes of the
Johnnies. On the next down, McCartee rounded left end for seven
yards, placing the ball on the threeyard line, and Armacost, on the last
down, carried the ball over for St.
John's first score. McCartee placekicked goal for the extra point.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 19, 1929

MARSHALL ADDRESSES
HOPKINS LIBERAL CLUB

DORM DOINGS
After close and careful observation of the inmates of Goucher for
several nights, months, and years
and their methods of leaving their
respective dormitories; several master-minds of the Johns Hopkins
Alumni Dormitory got their heads
together and considered the possibilities of applying the same principles to themselves. However,
after a lengthy discussion of the
vital question, it was decided to let
the plan stand as only a theory and
never make any definite attempts to

ANOTHER TRADITION CRUMBLES ALONG
WITH FRESHMEN REGULATIONS ET AL
The progress of light and learning at this revered institution has
decreed that the St. John's parade
become a thing of the past. One
by one the traditions fall. No more
shall Charles Street witness the
spectacle of enthusiastic students
marching to the strain of Hopkins
melodies. No more will the fair
damsels of Goucher College be
aroused out of dormitory beds at
nine o'clock to listen to the serenaders. No more shall Sun Square
be the scene of the final beheading
and cremation of the effigy of old
St. John's.
As we shed a last tear and turn
to our books for consolation let us
recall events of former years:
Every Freshman brought two
boxes of ample size and deposited
them in a pile behind the C. E. Hall
as per instructions of sopphomores.
In the course of a day or two the
pile has grown to enormous proportions. So much for preliminaries
and now our picture again changes.
The University Officials and police have put a ban on this part of
the celebration. What can be done?
Will the bon-fire be started anyhow? Page Frank Merriwell.
Seven o'clock and utter darkness.
A hugh crowd around the pile of
boxes, thirty feet high—just aching
to get hot. Here and there small
groups of students are planning
What can be done? Policemen, some fifty strong prevent anyone from getting near the hugh bier.
St. John's in dummy form, is rest-

ing calmly upon the great heap, and
no doubt is thumbing his nose at
the frustrated and disappointed
student body.
Suddenly, without warning, a
collegiate Ford is seen hurtling at
a terrific speed right for the crowd.
The crowd, awe struck and frightened, moves aside; policemen are
cleverly taken care of; the car flies
past dropping a flaming torch as it
goes, and the deed is done.
As the last flaming ember dies
away the parade begins its march
down Charles Street. Goucher
College' is serenaded, looked over,
dated up, and the parade moves on.
The semaphore station at Charles
Street and North Avenue is converted into a cheer leaders stand.
Mysterious chemicals on the car
tracks explode loudly. Finally one
great mass of hoarse throats gather
at the Sun Square and yell and
yell and sing, and announce in no
uncertain terms that the good ole'
"Black and Blue" eleven will throttle decisively an Orange and Black
jerseyed team.

1929 HULLABALOO TO.
GIVE DANCE NOV. 28
The staff of the 1929 Hullabaloo will sponsor a Thanksgiving dance at 9:00 P. M.
Thanksgiving Day at the
Southern Hotel. This dance,
which was to be the regular
after-the-game dance of the
Cotillion Club, was turned
over to the Hullabaloo staff
in order that they might make
up a large deficit incurred
from publishing last year's
Hullabaloo. A large attendance is hoped for, so that the
deficit may be made up. A
charge of $1.00, stag or couple, will be made.

Armacose Scores

The second quarter was still
young when McCartee scooped up
the ball and ran it back 25 yards.
Dublin followed, and matched this
run with another for the same gain,
again placing St. John's ill a scoring position. In two downs, with
Lynch and Dublin bucking the line,
the Johnnies gained a first down,
and the ball rested on Hopkins'
eight-yard line. Over again the Jays
braced themselves, but Armacost
took the joy out of life for them
by running around the right end for
six points.
Fourth Quarter Lively

Early in the last period St. John's
scored its fourth touchdown, resulting from some more of McCartee's elusive running. After
running a kick back 30 yards, to,
the Jays' 20-yard line, on the next
yards to cross the Hopkins' goal
from Lynch and went over for a
touchdown.
About six minutes still remained
to be played when McCartee broke
loose for the last time. He took
the ball on his own.team's 45-yard
line and by sidestepping, spinning,
eluding tacklers and running like a
scared rabbit, he was able to run 55
yards to cros sthe Hopkins' goal
line for St. John's last touchdown_
Hopkins Shows Form

At times during the game the
Jays played good football and St.
John's, as a machine, during these
times, seemed very unimpressive.
,The Jays played well during the last
eight minutes of the first quarter,
the concluding 15 minutes in the
second quarter and for the first 10
minutes of the third quarter. On
the defense Hopkins played well,
but it was plainly brought out that
what is lacking is a good offensive
machine.
